awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nanoimprinting of High Aspect-Ratio Nanostructures in Thermoplastic Polymers Using Metallic Glass Roller Molds
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative research team uses a multidisciplinary approach to investigate the feasibility of scalable imprinting of thermoplastic polymer film surfaces enabled by the use of metallic glass roller molds. Thermoplastic polymers with high aspect-ratio nanoscale features exhibit versatile properties and are highly desired in numerous applications such as solar cells, transparent conducting films and photonic crystals. Manufacturing such films with nanoscale features using roll-to-roll (R2R) nanoimprinting has been developed for reactive polymers but has been a challenge for thermoplastic polymers because they are typically over 100 times more viscous and require significantly higher imprinting pressure. Hence, there emerges a need for the development of a precise and durable roller mold for thermoplastic nanoimprinting. This collaborative project involves two institutions, one leading investigations into the design and roll-to-roll manufacture of the high aspect-ratio nanostructures in thermoplastic substrates, the other directing efforts in characterization and modeling. Results from this research forms the scientific basis for successful transfer of the novel manufacturing technology to industry and enables economic production of nanodevices for applications in energy, healthcare, automotive, and telecommunication. The project further enriches curriculum development, particularly in the interdisciplinary area of nanomanufacturing, and broadens the participation of women and underrepresented groups in research. 

This award supports fundamental research to explore a viable nanomanufacturing process using a mechanically robust metallic glass roller mold for continuous production of high-fidelity thermoplastic nanostructures. Metallic glasses are a class of high strength metals that can be processed like plastics in their supercooled liquid state into large-scale geometries with feature sizes down to 10 nm. The project involves several tasks. (1) Investigations into the transfer of planar nanostructures onto the curved surface of metallic glass coated roller molds. (2) Identification of the thermomechanical processing window for roller nanoimprinting of metallic glasses without crystallization. (3) Utilization of proximity heating to enhance the replication precision. (4) Characterization of the replication fidelity of the imprinted nanostructures. (5) Performance of numerical modeling of roll-to-roll based nanomanufacturing processes. Fundamental contributions are anticipated regarding the nanoscale dynamics of metallic glasses and thermoplastic polymers during continuous nanoimprinting. Particularly, the research advances the understanding of (a) rheology and processing-microstructure-property relations in metallic glasses and thermoplastic polymers at nanoscale, (b) crystallization of metallic glasses in the supercooled liquid regime, and (c) precise control and optimization of material?s thermomechanical history in nanoscale fabrication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The demand for cost-effective fabrication of nano- and micro-structured polymer films has surged across diverse sectors such as biotechnology and telecommunications. However, progress faces a significant obstacle in the creation of nanostructured roller molds. Addressing this challenge was the central goal of a collaborative initiative between the University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMass) and the Georgia Institute of Technology (Georgia Tech). The joint effort aimed to overcome the hurdle by employing metallic glass (MG) coated roller molds with nano/microstructured surfaces. The focus was on determining the viability of developing nanostructured metallic glass roller molds for scalable roll-to-roll nanomanufacturing of thermoplastic nanostructures. The project integrated experimental work, centered at UMass, and modeling plus simulation efforts led by Georgia Tech. UMass concentrated on experimental work, fabricating MG roller molds through roller imprinting, continuous patterning of thermoplastic polymers via roll-to-roll (R2R) imprinting, and optimizing these processes. Meanwhile, Georgia Tech delved into modeling and fundamental studies on the deformation dynamics of metallic glasses during thermoplastic imprinting.

Key accomplishments at Georgia Tech involved: (1) Establishing a micro-colloidal model to describe MG rheology; (2) Developing a Smoothed Dissipative Particle Dynamics (SDPD) model for imprinting and embossing simulations; (3) Creating a continuum-based imprinting simulation considering microscale size effects; (4) Investigating disparities and similarities between SDPD and Finite Element Method (FEM) simulations to formulate a unified model. These endeavors resulted in versatile simulation capabilities for imprinting and embossing of BMGs and polymers. The simulations aided in determining suitable process parameters for imprinting and enhanced the fundamental understanding of nanoimprinting mechanics. Furthermore, Georgia Tech collaborated with UMass to construct a roll-based imprinting mechanism for hot embossing MG cylindrical rollers with micro- or nano-structures. The embossed MG rollers effectively transferred features to thermoplastic polymers in a roll-to-roll thermal embossing process.

This collaborative research culminated in a novel nanomanufacturing process capable of continuously producing micro/nanostructured thermoplastic polymers using MG roller molds. The findings provide a scientific foundation for transitioning this innovative nanomanufacturing technology into industry applications. Moreover, the project made fundamental contributions in particle-based simulations, micro-rheology, and simulations incorporating size-dependent viscosity. The project further promotes teaching, training, and learning through multi-discipline approaches, broadens the participation of undergraduate students (through REU supplements), and enriches the curricula for Polymer Processing courses at both undergraduate and graduate levels.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2023
Modified by: Donggang Yao
